steps.title: Place your hook through the loop.
steps.content: Place your hook through the loop. Which loop you choose will partially depend on your pattern, but in a basic stitch, it should be the next loop over or the one after that. You can identify the loops by laying your work flat and looking at the bumps along the top edge where you are working. Your hook should be going in the front and out the back of the loop. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Catch the yarn.
steps.content: Catch the yarn. Hook the yarn so that the yarn is facing you. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the yarn.
steps.content: Pull the yarn. Pull the yarn back through the loop. You should now see two loops of yarn on your hook. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Catch the yarn again.
steps.content: Catch the yarn again. Hook the yarn so that the yarn is facing you again. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the yarn again.
steps.content: Pull the yarn again. Pull the yarn back through the two loops on your hook. You may need to turn the face of your hook down towards your piece. When you are done you should be left with a single loop again. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat the process.
steps.content: Repeat the process. For the next stitch, avoid the loop which is pulled upward into your current stitch. Go for the next loop instead. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Plan the right number of chain stitches.
steps.content: Plan the right number of chain stitches. If you are starting a piece from scratch, you'll have to make a chain before you can single crochet. First, you'll want to chain the number of single-crochet stitches you'd like to create, plus one or two, depending on which stitch you will be using in the next row. Figure out how many you need and continue. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Make a slipknot.
steps.content: Make a slipknot. To crochet chain stitches, first tie a slip knot and poke the crochet hook through the knot.

steps.title: Hold the yarn and hook correctly.
steps.content: Hold the yarn and hook correctly. Hold the crochet hook in one hand, and the end of the yarn that leads back to the skein in the other. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap the yarn.
steps.content: Wrap the yarn. Wrap the end of the yarn around the hook once, starting behind the hook and coming up and over until the yarn lies beneath the hook itself. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the yarn.
steps.content: Pull the yarn. Pull the hook through the slip knot, drawing the yarn you just wrapped along with it. You've just chained 1 stitch and have a new loop of yarn around the hook for making your next chain. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat.
steps.content: Repeat. Repeat the process, wrapping the yarn around the hook and pulling it through the loop until you've chained the desired number of stitches. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Chain one stitch.
steps.content: Chain one stitch. Turn your work. Once you've done your chain row, or a row of single crochet, you'll have to turn around and do another row. In other words, hold the hook still while you flip the chain you just made from either right to left, or left to right. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Find the next stitch.
steps.content: Find the next stitch. Identify the second chain stitch away from your crochet hook. In other words, skip the chain stitch and go on to the first single crochet stitch. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Insert the hook.
steps.content: Insert the hook. Poke the hook through the top of this stitch, from front to back. Continue as described in the first section. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Make one chain stitch at the end.
steps.content: Make one chain stitch at the end. At the end of each row, always chain 1 more stitch, turn your work, and repeat the process back across the row. [15] X Research source
